original: dakṣa upasthiteṣu jñātavyeṣu kartavyeṣu ca sadya eva jñātuṃ kartuṃ ca samarthaḥ /
analyzed: dakṣaḥ upasthiteṣu jñātavyeṣu kartavyeṣu ca sadyas eva jñātum kartum ca samarthaḥ
translated: He is skillful, able to know and do immediately what is to be known and done that has presented itself.

original: udāsīno na kasyacin mitrādeḥ pakṣaṃ bhajate yaḥ /🔽gatavyathaḥ parais tāḍyamānasyāpi gatā notpannā vyathā pīḍā yasya saḥ /
analyzed: udāsīnaḥ na kasyacid mitra ādeḥ pakṣam bhajate yaḥ  gata vyathaḥ paraiḥ tāḍyamānasya api gatā nā utpannā vyathā pīḍā yasya saḥ
translated: He is neutral, not taking sides with anyone, friend or the like.🔽He is free from pain, for whom pain, affliction, has not arisen even when struck by others.

original: utpannāyām api vyathāyām apakarṛṣv anapakartṛtvaṃ kṣamitvam /
analyzed: utpannāyām api vyathāyām apakarṛṣu anapakartṛ tvam kṣami tvam
translated: Even when pain has arisen, forgiveness is not retaliating against one who has harmed.

original: vyathākāraṇeṣu satsv apy anutpannavyathatvaṃ gatagatavyathatvam iti bhedaḥ /
analyzed: vyathā kāraṇeṣu satsu api anutpanna vyatha tvam gata gata vyathā tvam iti bhedaḥ
translated: The difference is that even when the causes of pain exist, he has no pain that has arisen. He is free from pain that has arisen.

original: aihikāmuṣmikaphalāni sarvāṇi karmāṇi sarvārambhās tān parityaktuṃ śīlaṃ yasya sa sarvārambhaparityāgī sannyāsī yo madbhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
analyzed: aihika āmuṣmika phalāni sarvāṇi karmāṇi sarva ārambhāḥ tān parityaktum śīlam yasya sa sarva ārambha parityāgī sannyāsī yaḥ mad bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
translated: He who has the habit of renouncing all actions, worldly and other-worldly, all undertakings, is a renunciate, a devotee of Mine, he is dear to Me.

original: viśvanāthaḥ anapekṣo vyavahārikakāryāpekṣārahita udāsīno vyavahārikalokeṣv anāsaktaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha: An-apeksah, indifferent, free from the desire for worldly duties, unattached to worldly people.

original: sarvān vyavahārikān dṛṣṭādṛṣṭārthāṃs tathā pāramārthikān api kāṃścit śāstrādhyāpanādīn ārambhān udyamān parihartuṃ śīlaṃ yasya saḥ ////
analyzed: sarvān vyavahārikān dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa arthān tathā pāramārthikān api kāṃścid śāstra adhyāpana ādīn ārambhān udyamān parihartum śīlam yasya saḥ
translated: He who has the habit of avoiding all worldly duties, seen and unseen, and some even of the spiritual duties such as teaching scriptures, etc.

original: baladevaḥ anapekṣaḥ svayam āgate 'pi bhogye nispṛhaḥ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ anapekṣaḥ svayam āgate bhogye nispṛhaḥ
translated: Balarama: An-apeksah, indifferent, free from desire even for enjoyments that come of their own accord.

original: śucir bāhyābhyantarapāvitryavān /
analyzed: śuciḥ bāhya abhyantara pāvitryavān
translated: Sucir, pure, externally and internally.

original: dakṣaḥ svaśāstrārthavimarśasamarthaḥ /
translated: Dakshah, skillful, capable of discerning the meaning of his scriptures.

original: udāsīnaṃu parapakṣāgrāhī /
analyzed: para pakṣa agrāhī
translated: Udasinam, neutral, not taking sides with others.

original: gatavyatho 'pakṛto 'py ādhiśūnyaḥ /
analyzed: gata vyathaḥ pakṛtaḥ pi ādhi śūnyaḥ
translated: Gata-vyatha, free from distress, devoid of anxiety even when wronged.

original: sarvārambhaparityāgī svabhaktipratīpākhilodyamarahitaḥ ////
translated: Sarva-arambha-parityagih, free from all undertakings opposed to devotion to Me.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati /
analyzed: yaḥ na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati
translated: He who neither rejoices nor hates, neither grieves nor desires,

original: śubhāśubhaparityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ ////
analyzed: śubha aśubha parityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ
translated: He who has renounced good and evil, and is devoted, is dear to Me.

original: śrīdharaḥ kiṃ ca ya iti /🔽priyaṃ prāpya yo na hṛṣyati /
analyzed: ca   iti  priyam prāpya yaḥ na hṛṣyati
translated: Śrīdhara: What is more, he who...🔽He who does not rejoice on obtaining what is dear.

original: apriyaṃ prāpya yo na dveṣṭi /🔽iṣṭārthanāśe sati yo na śocati /
analyzed: apriyam prāpya yaḥ na dveṣṭi  iṣṭa artha nāśe sati yaḥ na śocati
translated: He who does not hate on obtaining what is not dear.🔽He who does not grieve when desired objects are destroyed.

original: aprāptam arthaṃ yo na kāṅkṣati /
analyzed: a prāptam artham yaḥ na kāṅkṣati
translated: He who does not long for what is not obtained.

original: śubhāśubhe puṇyapāpe parityaktuṃ śīlaṃ yasya saḥ /
analyzed: śubha aśubhe puṇya pāpe parityaktum śīlam yasya saḥ
translated: He who has the habit of renouncing good and evil, merit and sin.

original: evaṃbhūto bhūtvā yo madbhaktimān sa me priyaḥ ////
analyzed: evaṃbhūtaḥ bhūtvā yaḥ mad bhaktimān sa me priyaḥ
translated: Having become such, he who is devoted to Me is dear to Me.

original: madhusūdanaḥ kiṃ ca ya iti /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ kim ca yaḥ iti
translated: Madhusūdana: What is more, he who...

original: samaduḥkhasukha ity etad vivṛṇoti /
analyzed: sama duḥkha sukhaḥ iti etat vivṛṇoti
translated: This is explained by equal in pain and pleasure.

original: yo na hṛṣyatīṣṭaprāptau /
analyzed: yaḥ na hṛṣyati iṣṭa prāptau
translated: He who does not rejoice on obtaining what is dear.

original: na dveṣṭi aniṣṭaprāptau na śocati prāpteṣṭaviyoge /
analyzed: na dveṣṭi aniṣṭa prāptau na śocati prāpta iṣṭa viyoge
translated: He who does not hate on obtaining what is not dear, does not grieve when separated from what is obtained and desired,

original: na kāṅkṣati aprāpteṣṭayoge /
analyzed: na kāṅkṣati aprāpta iṣṭa yoge
translated: does not long for what is not obtained and desired.

original: sarvārambhaparityāgīty etad vivṛṇoti śubhāśubhe sukhasādhanaduḥkhasādhane karmaṇī parityaktuṃ śīlam asyeti śubhāśubhaparityāgī bhaktimān
analyzed: sarva ārambha parityāgī iti etat vivṛṇoti śubha aśubhe sukha sādhana duḥkha sādhane karmaṇī parityaktum śīlam asya iti śubha aśubha parityāgī bhaktimān
translated: This is explained by he who has renounced all undertakings. He who has the habit of renouncing good and evil, the actions that are the means of happiness and suffering, is the renouncer of good and evil. He who is devoted

original: yaḥ sa me priyaḥ ////
analyzed: yaḥ sa me priyaḥ
translated: to Me is dear to Me.

original: viśvanāthaḥ Nothing /
analyzed: viśvanāthaḥ nothing
translated: Viṣṇu: Nothing.

original: baladevaḥ yaḥ priyaṃ putraśiṣyādi prāpya na hṛṣyati /
analyzed: baladevaḥ yaḥ priyam putra śiṣya ādi prāpya na hṛṣyati
translated: Balarāma: He who, on obtaining what is dear, such as a son or disciple, does not rejoice,

original: apriyaṃ tat prāpya tatra na dveṣṭi /
analyzed: apriyam tat prāpya tatra na dveṣṭi
translated: Having obtained that which is unpleasant, he does not hate it there.

original: priye tasmin vinaṣṭe na śocati /
analyzed: priye tasmin vinaṣṭe na śocati
translated: When that which is pleasant is destroyed, he does not grieve.

original: aprāptam tan nākāṅkṣati /
analyzed: a prāptam tat na ākāṅkṣati
translated: He does not long for that which is not obtained.

original: śubhaṃ puṇyam aśubhaṃ pāpaṃ tadubhayaṃ pratibandhakatvasāmyāt parityaktuṃ śīlaṃ yasya saḥ ////
analyzed: śubham puṇyam aśubham pāpam tat ubhayam pratibandhaka tva sāmyāt parityaktum śīlam yasya saḥ
translated: He has a tendency to abandon both good, i.e., meritorious, and bad, i.e., sinful, actions, considering them to be equally obstructive.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ /
analyzed: samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā māna apamānayoḥ
translated: Equal towards friend and foe, and likewise towards honor and dishonor,

original: śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkheṣu samaḥ saṅgavivarjitaḥ ////
analyzed: śīta uṣṇa sukha duḥkheṣu samaḥ saṅga vivarjitaḥ
translated: Equal towards cold and heat, pleasure and pain, free from attachment.

original: tulyanindāstutir maunī saṃtuṣṭo yena kenacit /
analyzed: tulya nindā stutiḥ maunī saṃtuṣṭaḥ yena kenacid
translated: Equal towards praise and blame, silent, content with anything,

original: aniketaḥ sthiramatir bhaktimān me priyo naraḥ ////
analyzed: aniketaḥ sthira matiḥ bhaktimān me priyaḥ naraḥ
translated: Homeless, of steady mind, devoted, that man is dear to Me.

original: śrīdharaḥ kiṃ ca sama iti /🔽śatrau ca mitre ca sama ekarūpaḥ /
analyzed: ca   iti  śatrau ca mitre ca samaḥ eka rūpaḥ
translated: And what? Equal, etc.🔽Equal, of one form, towards friend and foe.

original: mānāpamānayor api tathā sama eva /
analyzed: māna apamānayoḥ api tathā samaḥ eva
translated: Likewise equal towards honor and dishonor also.

original: harṣaviṣādaśūnya ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: harṣa viṣāda śūnyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is, devoid of joy and sorrow.

original: śītoṣṇayoḥ sukhaduḥkhayoś ca samaḥ /
analyzed: śīta uṣṇayoḥ sukha duḥkhayoḥ ca samaḥ
translated: Equal towards cold and heat, pleasure and pain.

original: saṅgavivarjitaḥ kvacid apy anāsaktaḥ ////
analyzed: saṅga vivarjitaḥ kvacid api anāsaktaḥ
translated: Free from attachment, unattached to anything.

original: kiṃ ca tulyanindāstutir iti /
analyzed: kim ca tulya nindā stutiḥ iti
translated: And what? Equal towards praise and blame, etc.

original: tulyā nindāstutiś ca yasya saḥ /
analyzed: tulyā nindā stutiḥ ca yasya saḥ
translated: He who is equal towards praise and blame.

original: maunī saṃyatavāk /
analyzed: maunī saṃyata vāc
translated: Silent, restrained in speech.

original: yena kenacit yathālabdhena saṃtuṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yena kenacid yathālabdhena saṃtuṣṭaḥ
translated: He is satisfied with whatever he gets.

original: aniketo niyatāvāsaśūnyaḥ /
analyzed: aniketaḥ niyata āvāsa śūnyaḥ
translated: He is homeless, devoid of a fixed residence.

original: sthiramatir vyavasthitacittaḥ /
analyzed: sthira matiḥ vyavasthita cittaḥ
translated: He has a firm mind, a settled heart.

original: evaṃbhūto bhaktimān yaḥ sa naro mama priyaḥ ////
analyzed: evaṃbhūtaḥ bhaktimān yaḥ sa naraḥ mama priyaḥ
translated: Such a devoted man is dear to Me.

original: madhusūdanaḥ kiṃ ca sama iti /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ kim ca samaḥ iti
translated: Madhusudana. And what? He is impartial, etc.

original: pūrvasyaiva prapañcaḥ /🔽saṅgavivarjitaś cetanācetanasarvaviṣayaśobhanādhyāsarahitaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvasya eva prapañcaḥ  saṅga vivarjitaḥ cetana acetana sarva viṣaya śobhana adhyāsa rahitaḥ
translated: This is an elaboration of the previous [verse].🔽He is free from attachment, devoid of superimposition of beauty on all objects, animate and inanimate.

original: sarvadā harṣaviṣādaśūnya ity arthaḥ / spaṣṭam ////
analyzed: sarvadā harṣa viṣāda śūnyaḥ iti arthaḥ spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is that he is always devoid of joy and sorrow. It is clear.

original: kiṃ ca tulyanindāstutir iti /
analyzed: kim ca tulya nindā stutiḥ iti
translated: And what? He is the same in praise and blame.

original: nindā doṣakathanam /
analyzed: nindā doṣa kathanam
translated: Blame is the statement of faults.

original: stutir guṇakathanam /
analyzed: stutiḥ guṇa kathanam
translated: Praise is the statement of virtues.

original: te duḥkhasukhājanakatayā tulye yasya sa tathā /
analyzed: te duḥkha sukha ajanaka tayā tulye yasya sa tathā
translated: He who has them as equal because they do not cause pain and pleasure is so.

original: maunī saṃyatavāk /
analyzed: maunī saṃyata vāc
translated: He is silent, his speech is restrained.

original: nanu śarīrayātrānirvāhāya vāgvyāpāro 'pekṣita eva nety āha saṃtuṣṭo nivṛttaspṛhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu śarīra yātrā nirvāhāya vāc vyāpāraḥ upekṣitaḥ eva nā iti āha saṃtuṣṭaḥ nivṛtta spṛhaḥ
translated: But speech activity is indeed required for the sake of maintaining the body, he says: satisfied, his desires ceased.

original: kiṃ ca aniketo niyatanivāsarahitaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca aniketaḥ niyata nivāsa rahitaḥ
translated: And what? He is homeless, devoid of a fixed residence.

original: sthirā paramārthavastuviṣayā matir yasya sa sthiramatiḥ /
analyzed: sthirā paramārtha vastu viṣayā matiḥ yasya sa sthira matiḥ
translated: He whose mind is firm, having the highest truth as its object, is one with a firm mind.

original: īdṛśo yo bhaktimān sa me priyo naraḥ /
analyzed: īdṛśaḥ yaḥ bhaktimān sa me priyaḥ naraḥ
translated: Such a devoted man is dear to Me.

original: atra punaḥ punar bhakter upādānaṃ bhaktir evāpavargasya puṣkalaṃ kāraṇam iti draḍhayitum ////
analyzed: atra punar punar bhakteḥ upādānam bhaktiḥ eva apavargasya puṣkalam kāraṇam iti draḍhayitum
translated: The repetition of the word bhakti (devotion) here is to emphasize that devotion alone is the most important cause of liberation.

original: viśvanāthaḥ aniketaḥ prākṛtasvāspadāsaktiśūnyaḥ ////
translated: One who has no fixed abode, i.e., who is free from attachment to ordinary dwelling places.

original: baladevaḥ samaḥ śatrau ceti sphuṭārthaḥ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ samaḥ śatrau ca iti sphuṭa arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is clear: one who is equal to an enemy.

original: saṅgavarjitaḥ kusaṅgaśūnyaḥ /
analyzed: saṅga varjitaḥ kusaṅga śūnyaḥ
translated: Free from association, i.e., devoid of bad company.

original: tulyeti nindayā duḥkhaṃ stutyā sukhaṃ ca yo na vindati /🔽maunī yatavāk sveṣṭamananaśīlo vā /
analyzed: tulyā iti nindayā duḥkham stutyā sukham ca yaḥ na vindati  maunī yata vāc sva iṣṭa manana śīlaḥ vā
translated: One who does not experience sorrow due to censure or happiness due to praise.🔽One who is silent, i.e., one who is restrained in speech and is inclined to contemplate on the Supreme.

original: yena kenacid adṛṣṭākṛṣṭena rukṣeṇa snigdhena vānnādinā santuṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yena kenacid adṛṣṭa ākṛṣṭena rukṣeṇa snigdhena vā annādinā santuṣṭaḥ
translated: Content with anything that comes by chance, be it rough or smooth, such as food etc.

original: aniketo niyatanivāsarahito niketamohaśūnyo vā /
analyzed: aniketaḥ niyata nivāsa rahitaḥ niketa moha śūnyaḥ vā
translated: One who has no fixed abode, i.e., who is free from a regular dwelling place, or who is devoid of the delusion of an abode.

original: sthiramatir niścitajñānaḥ /
analyzed: sthira matiḥ niścita jñānaḥ
translated: One of steady understanding, i.e., one who has firm knowledge.

original: eṣv adveṣṭety ādiṣu saptasu yeṣu guṇānāṃ punar apy abhidhānaṃ tat teṣām atidaurlabhyajñāpanārtham ity adoṣaḥ /
analyzed: eṣu a dveṣṭā iti ādiṣu saptasu yeṣu guṇānām punar api abhidhānam tat teṣām ati daurlabhya jñāpana artham iti adoṣaḥ
translated: There is no fault in repeating the qualities such as non-hatred etc. again, because it is to make known their extreme rarity.

original: sanniṣṭhādīnāṃ trividhānāṃ bhaktānāṃ sambhūya sthitā ete 'dveṣṭṛtvādayo dharmā yathāsambhavatāratamyenaiva sudhībhiḥ saṅgamanīyāḥ ////
analyzed: sanniṣṭha ādīnām trividhānām bhaktānām sambhūya sthitāḥ ete dveṣṭṛ tva ādayaḥ dharmāḥ yathā sambhava tāratamyena eva sudhībhiḥ saṅgamanīyāḥ
translated: These qualities such as non-hatred etc., which are collectively present in the three types of devotees beginning with the one devoted to the Lord, should be combined by the wise according to their respective degrees of intensity, as far as possible.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Bhagavad Gita 12.13-14)

original: ye tu dharmyāmṛtam idaṃ yathoktaṃ paryupāsate /
analyzed: ye tu dharmya amṛtam idam yathā uktam paryupāsate
translated: But those who, as instructed, worship this nectar of religion,

original: śraddadhānā matparamā bhaktās te 'tīva me priyāḥ ////
analyzed: śraddadhānāḥ mad paramāḥ bhaktāḥ te tīva me priyāḥ
translated: who are full of faith, who are devoted to Me, they are very dear to Me.

original: śrīdharaḥ / uktaṃ dharmajātaṃ sapahalam upasaṃharati ye tv iti /
translated: Sri Sridhara: To conclude the topic of religion with its auxiliaries, the Lord says, But those who...

original: yathoktam uktaprakāram /
analyzed: yathā uktam ukta prakāram
translated: As instructed means in the manner described.

original: dharma evāmṛtam /
analyzed: dharmaḥ eva amṛtam
translated: Religion itself is nectar.

original: amṛtatvasādhanatvāt /
analyzed: amṛta tva sādhana tvāt
translated: Because it is the means of attaining immortality.

original: dharmyāmṛtam iti kecit paṭhanti /
analyzed: dharmya amṛtam iti kecid paṭhanti
translated: Some read dharmyamritam (the nectar of religion).

original: ye tad upāsate 'nutiṣṭhanti śraddhāṃ kurvantaḥ /🔽matparāś ca santaḥ /
analyzed: ye tat upāsate nutiṣṭhanti śraddhām kurvantaḥ  mad parāḥ ca santaḥ
translated: Those who worship it, who practice it, who have faith in it,🔽and who are devoted to Me,

original: madbhaktās te 'tīva me priyā iti ////
analyzed: mad bhaktāḥ te tīva me priyāḥ iti
translated: they are very dear to Me.

original: duḥkham avyaktavartmaiva tadbahuvighnam ato budhaḥ /
analyzed: duḥkham avyakta vartmā eva tad bahu vighnam atas budhaḥ
translated: The path of the unmanifest is full of suffering and many obstacles, therefore the wise one

original: sukhaṃ kṛṣṇapadāmbhojaṃ bhaktisatpathavān bhajet //🔽iti śrīśrīdharasvāmikṛtāyāṃ bhagavadgītāṭīkāyāṃ subodhinyāṃ
analyzed: sukham kṛṣṇa pada ambhojam bhakti sat pathavān bhajet  iti śrī śrīdhara svāmi kṛtāyām bhagavadgītā ṭīkāyām subodhinyām
translated: should worship the lotus feet of Krishna, which are happiness, by the good path of devotion.

original: bhaktiyogo nāma dvādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: bhaktiyogaḥ nāma dvādaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twelfth chapter named The Yoga of Devotion in the commentary called Subodhini written by Sri Sridhara Svami on the Bhagavad Gita.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: adveṣṭety ādinākṣaropāsakādīnāṃ jīvanmuktānāṃ saṃnyāsināṃ lakṣaṇabhūtaṃ svabhāvasiddhaṃ dharmajātamuktam /
analyzed: adveṣṭa iti ādinā akṣara upāsaka ādīnām jīvanmuktānām saṃnyāsinām lakṣaṇa bhūtam svabhāva siddham dharma jātam uktam
translated: By not hating etc., the natural qualities of renunciate jivanmuktas who meditate on the imperishable are stated.

original: yathoktaṃ vārtike 🔽utpannātmāvabodhasya hy adveṣṭṛtvādayo guṇāḥ /
analyzed: yathā uktam vārtike  utpanna ātma avabodhasya hi a dveṣṭṛ tva ādayaḥ guṇāḥ
translated: As has been said in the Vartika:🔽For the qualities of non-hatred, etc. of one who has realized the Self,

original: ayatnato bhavanty eva na tu sādhanarūpiṇaḥ // iti /
analyzed: ayatnataḥ bhavanti eva na tu sādhana rūpiṇaḥ iti
translated: arise effortlessly, and are not of the nature of a means.

original: etad eva ca purā sthitaprajñalakṣaṇarūpeṇābhihitam /
analyzed: etat eva ca purā sthita prajña lakṣaṇa rūpeṇa abhihitam
translated: And this very thing has been stated earlier in the form of the characteristics of one whose mind is steady.

original: tad idaṃ dharmajātaṃ prayatnena sampādyamānaṃ mumukṣor mokṣasādhanaṃ bhavatīti pratipādayann upasaṃharati ye tv iti /
analyzed: tat idam dharma jātam prayatnena sampādyamānam mumukṣoḥ mokṣa sādhanam bhavati iti pratipādayan upasaṃharati ye tu iti
translated: And this group of qualities, when accomplished with effort, becomes the means of liberation for one who desires liberation. Teaching this, he concludes with But those...

original: ye tu saṃnyāsino mumukṣavo dharmāmṛtaṃ dharmarūpam amṛtasādhanatvād amṛtavad āsvādyatvād
analyzed: ye tu saṃnyāsinaḥ mumukṣavaḥ dharma amṛtam dharma rūpam amṛta sādhana tvāt amṛta vat āsvādya tvāt
translated: But those who are renunciants, who desire liberation, who taste the nectar of dharma, which is like nectar because it is the means of attaining immortality,

original: vedaṃ yathoktam adveṣṭā sarvabhūtānām ity ādinā pratipāditaṃ paryupāsate 'nutiṣṭhanti
analyzed: vedam yathā uktam a dveṣṭā sarva bhūtānām iti ādinā pratipāditam paryupāsate nutiṣṭhanti
translated: who attend upon the Veda as taught, beginning with non-hatred towards all beings, who practice it,

original: prayatnena śraddadhānāḥ santo matparamā ahaṃ bhagavān akṣarātmā vāsudeva eva paramaḥ🔽prāptavyo niratiśayā gatir yeṣāṃ te matparamā bhaktā māṃ nirupādhikaṃ brahma bhajamānās
analyzed: prayatnena śraddadhānāḥ santaḥ mad paramāḥ aham bhagavān akṣara ātmā vāsudevaḥ eva paramaḥ  prāptavyaḥ niratiśayā gatiḥ yeṣām te mad paramāḥ bhaktāḥ mām nirupādhikam brahma bhajamānāḥ
translated: who are endowed with faith and effort, who have Me as their highest, for whom the imperishable Self, Lord Vāsudeva, is the highest goal to be attained,

original: te 'tīva me priyāḥ /
analyzed: te tīva me priyāḥ
translated: those devotees are extremely dear to Me.

original: priyo hi jñānino 'tyartham ahaṃ sa ca mama priyaḥ iti pūrvasūcitasyāyam upasaṃhāraḥ /
analyzed: priyaḥ hi tyartham aham sa ca mama priyaḥ iti pūrva sūcitasya ayam upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: For the knower of the Self, I am very dear, and he is dear to Me. This is the conclusion of what was indicated earlier.

original: yasmād dharmāmṛtam idaṃ śraddhayānutiṣṭhan bhagavato viṣṇoḥ parameśvarasyātīva priyo
analyzed: yasmāt dharma amṛtam idam śraddhayā anutiṣṭhan bhagavataḥ viṣṇoḥ parameśvarasya atīva priyaḥ
translated: Because one who practices this nectar of Dharma with faith becomes extremely dear to Lord Vishnu, the Supreme God.

original: bhavati tasmād idaṃ jñānavataḥ svabhāvasiddhatayā lakṣaṇam api mumukṣuṇātmatattvajijñāsunātmajñānopāyatvena
analyzed: bhavati tasmāt idam jñānavataḥ svabhāva siddha tayā lakṣaṇam api mumukṣuṇā ātma tattva jijñāsunā ātma jñāna upāya tvena
translated: Therefore, this is the natural characteristic of one who has knowledge. One who desires liberation, who seeks to know the truth of the Self,

original: yatnād anuṣṭheyaṃ viṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padaṃ jigamiṣuṇeti vākyārthaḥ /
analyzed: yatnāt anuṣṭheyam viṣṇoḥ paramam padam jigamiṣuṇā iti vākya arthaḥ
translated: should strive to practice it as a means to the knowledge of the Self. One who desires to attain the highest abode of Vishnu should do so. This is the meaning of the sentence.

original: tad evaṃ sopādhikabrahmābhidhyānaparipākān nirupādhikaṃ brahmānusandadhānasyādveṣṭṛtvādidharmaviśiṣṭasya
analyzed: tat evam sa upādhika brahma abhidhyāna paripākāt nirupādhikam brahma anusandadhānasya a dveṣṭṛ tva ādi dharma viśiṣṭasya
translated: Thus, for the principal qualified person, who is endowed with the qualities of non-hatred etc., and who is contemplating on Brahman without any limiting adjunct, as a result of the maturity of the meditation on Brahman with limiting adjuncts,

original: mukhyasyādhikāriṇaḥ śravaṇamanananididhyāsanāny āvartayato vedāntavākyārthatattvasākṣātkārasambhavāt
analyzed: mukhyasya adhikāriṇaḥ śravaṇa manana nididhyāsanāni āvartayataḥ vedānta vākya artha tattva sākṣātkāra sambhavāt
translated: the realization of the truth of the meaning of the Vedanta statements occurs when he repeatedly engages in listening, reflection, and meditation.

original: tato muktyupapater muktihetuvedāntamahāvākyārthānvayayogyas tatpadārtho 'nusandheya
analyzed: tatas mukti upapateḥ mukti hetu vedānta mahāvākya artha anvaya yogyaḥ tad padārthaḥ nusandheya
translated: Therefore, the object of contemplation is suitable to be connected with the meaning of the great statements of the Vedanta, which are the cause of liberation.

original: iti madhyamena ṣaṭkena siddham // //
analyzed: iti madhyamena ṣaṭkena siddham
translated: Thus, it is established by the middle set of six.

original: iti śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīviśveśvarasarasvatīpāda
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus ends the twelfth chapter named The Yoga of Devotion in the Gītā, composed by Śrī Madhva.

original: śiṣyaśrīmadhusūdanasarasvatīviracitāyāṃ śrīmadbhagavadgītāgūḍhārthadīpikāyām bhaktiyogo nāma dvādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: śiṣya śrī madhusūdanasarasvatī viracitāyām śrīmat bhagavadgītā gūḍha artha dīpikāyām bhaktiyogaḥ nāma dvādaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: The commentary on the Gītā called Gūḍhartha-dīpikā, composed by the disciple of the great Śrī Viśveśvara Sarasvatī, the preceptor of the great Parivrājakācāryas, the illustrious Madhusūdana Sarasvatī, is completed.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: uktavān bahuvidhasvabhaktaniṣṭhān dharmān upasaṃharan kārtsnyenaitallipsūnāṃ tacchravaṇavicāraṇādiphalam āha ye tv iti /
analyzed: uktavān bahuvidha sva bhakta niṣṭhān dharmān upasaṃharan kārtsnyena etad lipsūnām tad śravaṇa vicāraṇa ādi phalam āha ye tu iti
translated: Having spoken of the various duties for devotees, he concludes by saying that those who desire this (devotion) get the fruit of listening to and contemplating it, by saying ye tu (those who).

original: ete bhaktyutthaśāntyutthadharmā na prākṛtā guṇāḥ bhaktyā tuṣyati kṛṣṇo na guṇaiḥ ity uktakoṭitaḥ /
analyzed: ete bhakti uttha śānti uttha dharmāḥ na prākṛtāḥ guṇāḥ bhaktyā tuṣyati kṛṣṇaḥ na guṇaiḥ iti ukta koṭitaḥ
translated: These duties arising from devotion and tranquility are not natural qualities. Kṛṣṇa is pleased by devotion, not by qualities. This is the meaning stated in the verse.

original: tu bhinnopakrame uktalakṣaṇā bhaktā ekaikasusvabhāvaniṣṭhāḥ /
analyzed: tu bhinna upakrame ukta lakṣaṇāḥ bhaktāḥ ekaika su svabhāva niṣṭhāḥ
translated: Tu (but) is used to introduce a different topic. Devotees with the characteristics mentioned are devoted to each good nature.

original: ete tu tattatsarvasallakṣaṇepsavaḥ sādhakā api tebhyaḥ siddhebhyo 'pi śreṣṭhāḥ /
analyzed: ete tu tad tad sarva sat lakṣaṇa īpsavaḥ sādhakāḥ api tebhyaḥ siddhebhyaḥ śreṣṭhāḥ
translated: But these aspirants, desiring all good characteristics, are even better than the perfected ones.

original: ataevāteti padam ////
analyzed: padam
translated: For this very reason, the word ate (they) is used.

original: sarvaśreṣṭhā sukhamayī sarvasādhyasusādhikā /
translated: Devotion is the best of all, full of bliss, and accomplishes all that is to be accomplished.

original: bhaktir evādbhutaguṇety adhyāyārtho nirūpitaḥ //
analyzed: bhaktiḥ eva adbhuta guṇā iti adhyāya arthaḥ nirūpitaḥ
translated: The wonderful quality of devotion has been described as the meaning of the chapter.

original: nimbadrākṣe iva jñānabhaktī yadyapi darśite /
analyzed: nimba drākṣe iva jñāna bhaktī yadi api darśite
translated: Although knowledge and devotion are shown to be like the neem and grapes,

original: ādīyete tad apy ete tattadāsvādalobhibhiḥ //
analyzed: ādīyete tat api ete tad tad āsvāda lobhibhiḥ
translated: They are still undertaken by those greedy for the taste of each.

original: iti sārārthavarṣiṇyāṃ harṣiṇyāṃ bhaktacetasām /
analyzed: iti sāra artha varṣiṇyām harṣiṇyām bhakta cetasām
translated: Thus, in the Gītā, which showers the essence, delights the minds of devotees,🔽The twelfth chapter is well-received by the good.

original: gītāsu dvādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ saṅgataḥ saṅgataḥ satām ////
analyzed: gītāsu dvādaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ saṅgataḥ saṅgataḥ satām
translated: [Śrīdhara: The twelfth chapter]

original: baladevaḥ / uktabhaktiyogam upasaṃharan tasmin niṣṭhāphalam āha ye tv iti /
translated: [Balarama:] Concluding the devotion described, he states the result of perfection in that, with the words But those who...

original: ye bhaktā yathoktaṃ mayy āveśya mano ye mām ity ādibhir yathāgatam idaṃ dharmāmṛtaṃ paryupāsate /
analyzed: ye bhaktāḥ yathoktam mayi āveśya manaḥ ye mām iti ādibhiḥ yathāgatam idam dharma amṛtam paryupāsate
translated: Those devotees who, as stated, have fixed their mind on Me, who have served this nectar of religion as it has come, with the words Those who...

original: prāpyaṃ mām iva prāpakaṃ tat samāśrayanti /
analyzed: prāpyam mām iva prāpakam tat samāśrayanti
translated: They resort to that which is the means of attaining Me, as if it were the goal itself.

original: śraddadhānā bhaktiśraddhālavo matparamā manniratās te mamātīva priyā bhavanti ////
analyzed: śraddadhānāḥ bhakti śraddhālavaḥ mad paramāḥ mad niratāḥ te mama atīva priyāḥ bhavanti
translated: Those who have faith, who are full of devotion and faith, who are devoted to Me, they become extremely dear to Me.

original: vaśaḥ svaikajuṣāṃ kṛṣṇaḥ svabhaktyekajuṣāṃ tu saḥ /
analyzed: vaśaḥ sva eka juṣām kṛṣṇaḥ sva bhakti eka juṣām tu saḥ
translated: [Śrīdhara: Kṛṣṇa is under the control of those who enjoy only Him, but He is under the control of those who enjoy only devotion to Him.

original: prītyaivātivaśaḥ śrīmān iti dvādaśanirṇayaḥ //
analyzed: prītyā eva ati vaśaḥ śrīmān iti dvādaśa nirṇayaḥ
translated: The glorious one is extremely under control only through love. This is the conclusion of the twelfth chapter.]

original: iti śrīmadbhagavadgītopaniṣadbhāṣye ekādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ
analyzed: iti śrīmat bhagavadgītā upaniṣad bhāṣye ekādaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eleventh chapter in the commentary on the Bhagavad Gītā.
